texts.shortText: Shell small, globular and winkle-like, whorls smoothly rounded (not with distinct angle between base and upper surface, as in some other species). Each whorl sculptured into several low spiral ridges; typically 2-3 more pronounced ridges, with finer ones between. Colour dark grey with oblique pale ‘flames’ crossing each whorl. Interior pale, operculum flat and horny.
Shell up to 9 mm in width, but typically less than 5 mm.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namaqualand to Cape Point.
Little is known about this small species, which is usually found in small groups on the undersides of boulders and in low-shore pools and gullies.
Unknown, but other members of this family generally browse on algae, diatoms and detritus on rocky substrata.

Reproduction in this species has not been studied. Other Northern hemisphere species in the genus, however, lay eggs in a jelly mass, the eggs frequently hatching only when the young have reached the crawling stage.

There are several other small, common Gibbula species in the region, and some of these are hard to identify to species in the field and require close examination of shell shape and/or colour pattern via a good quality close-up image, or examination under a microscope. This species is most similar to G. cicur in shell shape and colour pattern, but in that species narrow black and pale dashes follow the coils of the shell, whereas in G. beckeri larger pale ‘flames’ cross the whorls in an oblique manner.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 174)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 40).
